StandardDialog.Name: Dialog1
StandardDialog.DialogHeader: Raising Concerns Through Our Formal Complaint Process

QuizDialog.Name: QDialog1
QuizDialog.DialogBody: A local government official mentions that you’d be more likely to get a contract if you hired his son as a representative. Do you think you should hire him?

Rules.Rule: Please select your answer.
Correct. Our anti-corruption policy prohibits anyone in the organization from making bribes of any kind, anywhere in the world. In this case, the job could be considered an improper payment.
Please try again.

Page.Name: Introduction
Page.Text: Today we’re always connected, no matter the distance. We make connections through phones, chat, email, text messages, and the Internet.
We connect with our customers the same way and our entire operations have come to depend on those connections and all of the infrastructure that powers them.
Did you know an hour of network downtime costs on average $42,000?
Or that hackers and fraudsters make millions of dollars attacking computer systems, often by tricking end users into helping them?
Because you are given direct access through our firewalls, locked gates, and encryption systems, you’re a target for anyone trying to break into our systems or facilities.
We’re counting on you to make security minded decisions every day that will prevent security incidents and keep us secure.

Stage.Element:
About this Course

This short security awareness course covers the key security best practices you should follow so that you can prevent, detect, and respond to information security incidents.

At the end of this course is a final exam, which you must pass to receive course credit.
LESSON 1   ▶  Understanding Threats
LESSON 2   ▶  Safe Computing Best Practices
LESSON 3   ▶  Ensuring Physical Security
LESSON 4   ▶  Ensuring Data Security
LESSON 5   ▶  Mobile and Remote Computing Best Practices
LESSON 6   ▶  Summary
We protect information assets and capabilities from:
Other Forms of Attack

What Is Information Security?

Information security encompasses all the ways in which we protect our information assets and capabilities from unauthorized access, modification, or destruction and other forms of attack.  

Essentially, it is how we defend our computer systems and all of our valuable information in digital or hardcopy format, which in today's Information Age is absolutely critical to our organization.
Ensuring the security of information allows us to ensure the privacy of information, meaning that it is not exposed to the public or attackers. Click each icon below to learn more about privacy.

Personally Identifiable Information

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is defined as any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred, for example, names, addresses, and phone numbers.

Types of Private Data

PII, medical records, and personal financial information are the most common types of private data you may have access to. If you are uncertain whether or not some of the information you handle is private, ask your supervisor.

Safeguarding Private Data

Digital private data should always be password protected and encrypted when it is stored or transmitted. Encryption is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it. Hardcopy private data should always be stored under lock and key.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Threats

To secure our information and ensure privacy, we first have to understand the threats we face.

A threat is a person, circumstance, or event that could harm our information assets or infrastructure or violate our physical security controls.
To learn more about typical threats you may face, click each item.

Social Engineering

When attempting to steal information or a person’s identity, a malicious hacker will often try to trick you into giving out sensitive information rather than actually breaking into your computer. This is called social engineering and is often done over the phone.

Phishing & SPAM

Phishing is a type of social engineering that typically happens via email. The most typical scam is sending out an unsolicited SPAM email that looks like it is coming from a legitimate bank. The email might ask you to “verify” your account number and PIN and redirect you to a fake website that looks just like the bank’s website, but when you enter your information it goes directly to the phisher rather than the bank.

Malware

Malicious software, or malware, is any program that seeks to do harm or steal information.

Data Thieves

Could someone be walking out the door with an internal database stored on a Micro SD card or USB drive? Could someone be taking pictures of sensitive information or items with a smartphone? Unfortunately the answer is yes. Be vigilant, protecting any sensitive information you manage from these devices.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.
Click on each item to learn more about the most common forms of malware.

Viruses and Worms

A virus is a malicious program that can “infect” other programs, carry out some mission such as deleting files or stealing information, and self replicate.

A worm is similar to a virus, but it is a program in and of itself and does not need to infect another program. It can also replicate itself over a network without any user interaction.

Trojan Horses

Trojan horse is the term used for any program with something malicious hidden inside such as a virus or worm. Most malware uses the Trojan horse technique to trick you into installing a malicious program.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Knowledge Challenge
To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Elements.Element: Which of the following do you think is NOT necessarily a sign that your computer has been infected by malware?

Answers.Answer: Certain programs such as Task Manager on Windows no longer work or shut down as soon as you open them.
A security program you’ve never heard of will not allow you to access anything on your computer until you pay a fee to “repair” it.
Pop-up advertisements appear even when you are not using the Internet.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

This is a sign that your computer has been infected by malware.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

This is a sign that your computer has been infected by malware.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

This is a sign that your computer has been infected by malware.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

This is not necessarily a sign that your computer has been infected by malware. All the other options are and you should contact the Help Desk if you notice any of these symptoms.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Elements.Element: As you’re walking into a building, someone in uniform approaches you and says she’s collecting all ID badges because new ones will be arriving tomorrow. What do you think you should do?

Answers.Answer: Ask your supervisor about it before taking action.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Hackers often use social engineering techniques to gain access, bit by bit, to an organization. Getting access badges is often a first step and posing as a fellow employee is not uncommon.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Elements.Element: A few days later, you notice someone waiting outside of a secure area as you unlock the door. He smiles, approaches you, introduces himself as Sam, and asks your name. He says he’s lost his keys. Should you let him in?

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Simply apologize and offer to contact security to help him. They can decide if he should be allowed in.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Elements.Element: Even though you didn’t let Sam in, someone else did and you see him there an hour later. You notice he’s telling a coworker that he’s with IT and asking for her username and password to install an upgrade. Should she give him the information?

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

You should never give your username or password to anyone and never give sensitive information to anyone until you’ve verified their identity, access rights, and need to know.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Stage.Element:
Safe Computing Best Practices

Hackers and cybercriminals target end-users because they have the login credentials, access rights, and information they’re after, such as internal confidential or trade secret information. They may also be after your bank account or credit card information, which could be used to steal money or make fraudulent purchases in your name.

The good news is there are lots of things you can do to prevent security incidents and protect your identity.

Password Best Practices

First of all, to help secure our network and your own identity, you should create a strong password, change it often, and keep it secret.
Additionally, your passwords should:
Be as long as possible and at least eight characters,
Not contain words found in a dictionary in any language, since password crackers will try those first,
Use a mix of upper and lower case letters, numbers, and special characters such as “#” or “&”,
Not contain easily guessed personal information such as your birthday or the name of your pet, and
Not be written down or shared with anyone.

How to Create Strong, Easy to Remember Passwords

The phrase method is an easy way to remember complicated passwords that are hard to crack.

Security Awareness training is important for everyone!

SAtii4e!

To use the phrase method:

  1. Choose a phrase that has numbers.
  2. Only use the first letter in each word.
  3. Use the proper case for each letter, just as it appears in the phrase.
  4. Use actual numbers whenever possible. Use the numeral “2” for “two” and the numeral “4” for “four” or “for.”
  5. Include punctuation, such as “?”, “.”, and “!”

Don’t remember the password, just remember the phrase.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Knowledge Challenge
To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Elements.Element: Which of the following passwords do you think is stronger?

Rules.Rule:

Please select your answer.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Substituting numbers for letters is a great way to make a passphrase strong.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Page.Name: Question 2

Elements.Element: What about these? (Which is stronger?)

Page.Rules:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.
y esta otra

Correct.

This password is eight characters long, contains upper and lowercase letters, a number, and a special character and is based on a phrase (This is one good piece of pizza!).

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Elements.Element: What about these? (Which is stronger?)

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Longer passwords are much harder to break so adding random characters to a phrase-based password makes it much stronger.

(This ; is ; one ; good ; piece ; of ; pizza! = T;i;1;g;p;o;p!)


Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Elements.Element: Who do you think you should share your password with?

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

You shouldn’t share your password with anyone.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Stage.Element:
Best Practices for Avoiding Malware

Avoiding malware is another important way to protect our information resources.

There are, of course, many defenses in place to protect you from malware such as antivirus and antispyware software, firewalls, and spam filters but these tools cannot protect you if you unwittingly cooperate with malware. To avoid malware:
Think before you click. Delete suspicious emails without opening them such as those from unknown users with attachments,
If you don’t really need certain browser plugins, like JAVA, Flash, or Acrobat, disable them to prevent malware infections,
If you think your computer does not have an up to date operating system or antivirus or antispyware program or is infected by malware, alert the Help Desk, and
Only install applications approved by the IT department to avoid accidentally installing malware.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Challenge Questions

Click the Next button below to begin.

Correct.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

You should alert the Help Desk if you are having trouble receiving regular updates to your antivirus or antispyware application or to your operating system.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Module.Name: Best Practices for Thwarting Social Engineers

Page.Name: Best Practices for Thwarting Social Engineers

Stage.Element:
Best Practices for Thwarting Social Engineers

Social engineers are experts at deception.
To thwart social engineers:
• Verify the identity of those who ask for sensitive information in person or over the phone before you release it,
• Do not give out information about other employees, remote network access, organizational practices, or strategies to any unknown individual, and

• If you think you are the victim of social engineering, gather as much information as you can such as the person’s name, telephone number, and what they are asking for and report it to your supervisor or the Help Desk.

In addition to the best practices mentioned so far, we also have a set of acceptable use policies that are designed to ensure both security and efficiency within our organization. Click each item to learn more.

Your Responsibilities

As a computer end-user, you are expected to use information resources in a responsible and legal manner for work-related purposes, demonstrating respect for security, ethics and privacy policies, intellectual property rights, and every individual’s right to freedom from intimidation and harassment.

Internet

Access to the Internet is provided to help you work more efficiently. While limited personal use of the Internet is allowed, use of the Internet must NOT :

  • Interfere with your work,
  • Involve obscene, sexually explicit, threatening, or illegal activity,
  • Violate any policies or laws, or
  • Consume excessive time or resources.

Email and Instant Messages (IM)

Email and Instant Messaging should NOT be used for the following:

  • Excessive personal communications,
  • Transmission or retransmission of inappropriate content,
  • Personal business or solicitation, or
  • Unauthorized transmission of sensitive information.

Social Media

If you access social media sites, follow these best practices to maximize security:

  • Do not post personal information that could be used by identity thieves such as your phone number, birthday, etc.,
  • Only allow “friends” to view your profile or posts or send you messages,
  • Do not accept friend invitations from those you do not know,
  • Turn on available security features such as SSL encryption and logon alerts, and
  • Be aware that a friend’s account can be hijacked and used for online scams wherein your “friend” asks for money.

Other Prohibited Activities

Other prohibited activities include:

  • Making, installing, or sharing illegal or pirated copies of software, and
  • Attempting to access secure data or resources without authorization.

Workplace Privacy

Please also be aware that our internal workplace infrastructure is monitored for abuse.

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Knowledge Challenge
To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following question.

Elements.Element: Which of the following do you think is allowed by our acceptable use policies?

Answers.Answer: Web-loafing: Excessive surfing of the web while at work.
A quick phone call to your spouse to coordinate childcare or some other activity.
Sending email messages with obscene, sexually explicit, or threatening content.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

Limited personal use of company resources such as phones is permitted.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Stage.Element: Without physical security, none of our information can be secured, which is why we’ve deployed entry controls at our facilities. Click each item to learn more about entry control best practices.
Badges? Yes, We Need Those Badges

Best Practices: Gates and Doors
  • Don’t allow others to gain entrance to a secure location or restricted zone without using their own badge, access card, or key code, a practice known as tailgating or piggy-backing, and
  • Never leave doors to sensitive locations open or unlocked.

Best Practices: Badges? Yes, We Need Those Badges
  • Never leave your ID badge or access card unguarded. It should be worn or with you at all times and never lent out,
  • If you lose your ID badge or access card, report it immediately, and
  • If you see someone without an ID badge or visitor’s badge, politely escort the person to the security desk for sign in or report it to security personnel right away.

Best Practices: Visitors
  • Visitors should be checked in, escorted at all times, always wear a visitor badge, and return their visitor badge before leaving,
  • Visitors should not be allowed to use cameras or recording equipment of any kind without special permission, and
  • If a visitor requests Internet access, ensure he or she is only given limited guest access. Ask your supervisor or the Help Desk if you need assistance setting this up.

Best Practices: Emergency Exits

Always be aware of the nearest emergency exit to your workspace.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Entry control has to do with external threats. But what about internal threats from malicious insiders, employees, or others with legitimate access to our facilities who may be out to steal from or otherwise do harm to our organization? Click each item to learn about best practices to protect against the malicious insider threat.

Clear Your Desk

While away from your desk:

  • Make sure all papers, removable media, and other items containing sensitive information are cleared from your desk and locked away, and
  • Logoff of or lock your computer to ensure it cannot be accessed by anyone while you are away.

A password protected screensaver can be used to automatically lock your computer after a certain period of inactivity.

Copiers and Printers

Did you know modern copiers and printers have hard drives, just like your computer, and store every document ever copied or printed? Ensure the data on these hard drives is digitally wiped clean by the IT department before the devices are disposed of.

Fax Snooping

Malicious insiders may attempt to steal information by intercepting inbound faxes. Be sure to be physically at a fax machine before someone sends sensitive information to it.

Shared Meeting Areas

Shared meeting areas should also be kept free of sensitive information. When you leave a meeting area, be sure to erase any whiteboards, take all documents with you, and be careful what you throw in the trash.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Ensuring data is safeguarded is a critical aspect of information security and an area where you can make a big difference. The best practices you should apply depend on the class of data you are dealing with. Click each folder to learn more about data classifications.

Confidential

Confidential data is data whose loss, corruption, or unauthorized disclosure would violate laws, regulations, or contracts and possibly damage our reputation. Examples include private healthcare, financial, or any other data that may be protected by privacy laws, trade secrets, proprietary data, and strategic plans.

Sensitive: Internal Use Only

All data not considered confidential, but also not approved for public use is considered sensitive. Sensitive data is data whose loss would inconvenience our organization but not cause financial harm or harm to our reputation. Examples include reports, schedules, or email messages free of confidential information.

Public

Public data is data that has been approved for public use, for example, annual reports, website content, and press releases.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Data Storage and Transmission Best Practices

Stage.Element: Data Storage and Transmission Best Practices
Now that you have a better understanding of data classifications, let’s review best practices for each type. Click each folder to learn more.

Confidential

Confidential data should be:

  • Marked “confidential,”
  • Have a limited, need to know distribution,
  • Be protected with advanced security when being stored including access control lists, passwords, and encryption for electronic data and locked storage areas for hardcopy data, and
  • Be encrypted when being transmitted with an approved encryption system such as secure email, secure http, or secure ftp.

Contact the Help Desk for assistance.

Sensitive: Internal Use Only

Sensitive data should be:

  • Marked “sensitive,”
  • Have a limited, need to know distribution, and
  • Be protected when being stored with access control lists and passwords.

Sensitive information does not require encryption for storage or transmission.

Public

Public data does not require any special security precautions.

Backups

In addition to preventing unauthorized access, securing information means ensuring it is not lost. Always save files to a location that you know is regularly backed up, such as a network or "home" directory.

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.
Data Retention & Disposal Best Practices

Certain types of data such as contracts and company policies must be retained for a set, legally required period of time. Please view the Data Retention Policy in the course Resource Library for additional information.To learn how different types of data should be disposed of once their retention period has expired, click each folder.

Proper Disposal of Confidential Data

Believe it or not, people will go through our garbage looking for confidential and sensitive information. That’s why we must properly dispose of those types of data by shredding or incinerating hardcopy files before disposing of them and physically destroying or wiping out all data on desktops, laptops, and removable media (e.g., USB drives, Micro SD cards, DVDs, or hard drives, etc.) before disposing of them.

The IT department can assist with this.

Proper Disposal of Sensitive Data

Sensitive data should be disposed of the same way as confidential data.

Proper Disposal of Public Data

There are no special requirements for disposing of public data.

Minimum Necessary Data

As a general rule, you should create, distribute, retain, and have access to only the minimum amount of data needed to perform your duties.

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Using Public Cloud Storage

Storing sensitive workplace information on public cloud storage services (e.g. iCloud or Google Drive) poses a serious security threat, because it places information outside of our organization’s control. And if the cloud storage service is hacked, which is not uncommon, the sensitive information could be exposed. This could violate policy, contractual obligations, and the law.

For optimum security, only use approved secure cloud storage services.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Challenge Questions
Which of the following do you think is true or false?

Elements.Element: Confidential data must be encrypted while it is stored or transmitted and always password protected.

Rules.Rule:

Correct.

Confidential data must be protected by these advanced security measures.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Rules.Rule:

Correct.

Any data not considered confidential is considered sensitive and for internal use only. Only data explicitly approved for public use can be shared with the public.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Module.Name: Mobile and Remote Computing Best Practices

Page.Name: Mobile and Remote Computing Best Practices

Elements.Element: Mobile and Remote Computing Best Practices

Stage.Element:
Protecting Mobile Data and Devices

Taking workplace information with you can help you be much more efficient while away from the workplace and is sometimes necessary to get the job done.  

However, doing so exposes our organization to the risk of losing data, or worse, exposing confidential data to the public, which could violate laws and lead to a public relations nightmare.

Page.Name: Protecting Mobile Data and Devices Interactivity

Stage.Element: Protecting Mobile Data and Devices
Before removing workplace data from our facilities, you should get supervisor permission. To learn more about additional best practices you should follow, click each item below.

All Mobile Data Devices
  • Only place workplace information on a mobile device if it is absolutely necessary and the device can protect it,
  • Remove workplace information when it is no longer needed,
  • If you must store workplace information on a mobile device, encrypt the data. Contact the Help Desk for assistance, and
  • Use a strong password on all mobile devices.

Smartphones and Tablets
  • Ensure your mobile operating system is up to date with the latest software updates,
  • Report a lost device that contains or can access workplace information immediately. The IT department can disable access to some workplace information, such as email and may be able to remotely wipe data on the device,
  • Only use trusted, regulated app stores, and
  • Never “jail-break” an iPhone or “root” an Android phone, since that turns off security features.

Hardcopy Files

Properly dispose of any sensitive or confidential information in hardcopy format that you remove from the workplace based on our security policy.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Mobile Device Policy – Bring Your Own Device

Stage.Element:
Mobile Device Policy – Bring Your Own Device

Please note that our policy allows for both organization-owned and, in some cases, personally-owned smartphones and tablets to store and transmit workplace information, such as email, contacts, and calendars.
However, before attempting to use a personal smartphone or tablet for business purposes, you must:
Contact the Help Desk to determine if you are eligible and to get assistance with device setup,
Understand that devices that can access organization resources, even if they are personally-owned, are subject to certain limitations and controls, such as remote wipe, and
Agree to abide by all acceptable use policies when using your device, such as security and respectful workplace requirements.

Mobile Device Policy

Please note that our policy only allows for organization owned and managed devices to store and transmit workplace information, such as email, contacts, and calendars.

Never attempt to use a personal smartphone or tablet for business purposes.

Page.Name: Working in Public Places Best Practices

Stage.Element:
Working in Public Places Best Practices

Did you know over 7% of employee laptops are lost or stolen before the end of their useful lifespan?

Working in public places can help you be more efficient, but also exposes us to additional risks. Please follow these best practices when working in public places:
Never discuss confidential information in public places. You never know who could be listening in,
Be careful when displaying workplace information on your screen in public places. Someone could be reading it over your shoulder (shoulder surfing),
Never leave mobile data devices in view where they could lure thieves, and

Remote Access Best Practices

Working remotely, for example from your home, is another situation in which you may have to remove data from the workplace and therefore requires special precautions.

Please keep the following in mind:
The same security policies and standards apply when working remotely as in the workplace,
Any computer used to remotely access the network must be approved, secured with antivirus and antispyware software and a personal firewall, and meet all other minimum security requirements, and
Remote access to the workplace network must be over a VPN connection, which secures all communications.

Travel Safety

When traveling to another city or country, the same best practices apply for protecting information you take with you. However, additional personal safety best practices should also be followed.

If you go on business trips, please click on the Travel Safety button below to learn more about protecting yourself while traveling.
Travel Safety

Travel Safety Best Practices

  • Itinerary

    Leave a complete itinerary and copies of important documents, like your ID and passport, with someone and check in with that person periodically.

  • Luggage Tags

    Ensure your luggage is tagged with your name, address, and phone number and not left unattended.

  • Transporting Items

    Do not transport items for others.

  • Business Gifts

    Be cautious with business gifts received overseas before returning home with them.

  • Taxis

    Only use registered taxi services and be sure you are dropped off at a safe, well-lit place.

  • Airport Rides

    If you are being picked up at the airport, verify the identity of the driver before getting in the car.

  • Displays of Wealth

    Avoid taking or displaying expensive equipment or jewelry.

  • Credit Cards

    Only take the credit cards and money that you need for the trip.

  • Hotel Safe

    Lock expensive items and a backup credit card in your hotel safe.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red Close button, then click Next below to continue.

Page.Name: Question 1
Page.Intro:
Knowledge Challenge
To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following question.

Elements.Element: All of the following are good ways to protect mobile data EXCEPT:

Answers.Answer: Encrypting workplace data on mobile devices.
Using a strong password on mobile devices.
Removing workplace data from mobile devices when it is no longer needed.
Using any wireless connection available to conduct business such as an un-encrypted connection at a café.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Please Try Again

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Correct.

You should only use encrypted wireless connections.

Click the Continue button below to proceed.

Stage.Element:
Summary

Securing our information resources is vital to our success and cannot be achieved without your help.

We’re counting on you to put the best practices outlined in this course to use immediately to secure our information and help ensure privacy.

Incident Response

We’re also depending on you to report any security incidents you are aware of so that the IT department can improve the overall security, performance, and reliability of the network.

An information security incident is a violation or imminent threat of violation of security policies, acceptable use policies, or standard security practices. Please report any security incidents by notifying your supervisor or the Help Desk.

Security Policy Acceptance

Our Information Security Policy(ies) can be downloaded and saved by clicking on the following link(s):

A link to your Information Security Policy
A link to your BYOD (Bring Your Own Device) Policy

It is the responsibility of each employee to read, understand and follow the policy standards, guidelines, processes, and procedures set forth in the Information Security Policy(ies). Please take a moment to review this policy(ies) before proceeding to the policy acceptance form on the next page.

Page.Name: Policy Acceptance Form
Page.IncompleteBox: You must accept our information security policy(ies) to complete this course and receive credit.
Page.SuccessBox: Thank you for accepting our Information Security Policy(ies). Please click the Continue button below to continue.
Page.InvalidBox: You must accept our information security policy(ies) to complete this course and receive credit.

Elements.Element: Please click I Accept below if you agree with this statement.

Policy

I hereby acknowledge that I have read, or shall read, understand, and agree to follow the standards, guidelines, best practices, processes, and procedures set forth in the Information Security Policy(ies). I understand that failure to comply with this policy(ies) can lead to disciplinary action, up to termination of employment.

Stage.Element:
Content Section Complete

You have completed the content section of this course. You can now review the material or go directly to the final exam. The exam questions focus on what users can do to help make the network more secure.

Course Complete

Thank you for completing this course.

You may now exit by clicking the Exit button.
